job_title: Operations Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Excellent Leadership Professional Development Altruisitc Mission
cons: Does not offer Fully Remote

pros:
Great for new college grads. Because it's a non-profit, you have to do everything yourself: marketing, outreach, policy work, logistics, grant work, fundraising, event planning, etc. Great way to learn quickly and fine tone your ability to work efficiently and effectively - because you are stretched so thin. You can also take advantage of this to discover which pathway you want to grow into: policy, community organizing, program management, development, etc. Then you can tailor your work experience to focus on that area to boost your resume before transitioning into a new company.
Also, you can get training for free through coursera and other non-profit opportunities.
cons: Leadership does not invest in top entry-level talent. Instead, leadership promotes staff who are often disorganized, sometimes (rarely) they can also be micro-managers. Really sad because the lower level staff are the ones who do great work for the community. There is definitely a power dynamic and its tough to have transparent conversations with leadership about this. Those conversations often get dismissed with vague, yet strategically flamboyant, answers.

pros: You have the opportunity to help people and make a difference in the community. The work they do is really important and necessary.
cons: Work regime changes can sometimes negatively impact you. I felt I wasn’t being utilized to my full potential and others who had performed less were being promoted more easily.

pros: Great people with a meaningful mission
cons: The pay, but I wasn't surprised.

pros: I had an incredible experience working at CAIR. My time at the local chapter opened up many opportunities for me.
cons: Had the salary been higher, I likely would have stayed longer.

pros: Employee centered work culture, transparency, flexible working conditions.
cons: Can have a more stable financial situation. Management is working on doing so.

pros: good team, meaningful work, flexible
cons: large workload, time sensitive work, noncompetitive pay

pros: professional team, professional and peaceful environment.
cons: Nothing stands out for me at the moment.

pros: the people that you help

pros: If you have an affinity to helping the community this is the organization for you. Teams work together and work towards important causes that provide assistance and access to information to the community. It has grown immensely over the years and will continue to grow.
cons: This is a non profit organization and like any other you must be passionate to work for the community.

review_title: Great cause though work expectations are stressful

review_title: Good place to learn from a non profit
pros: Good place to work and grow from when you first start. You are able to collaborate with other departments and gain insight on what you do not want in your career.
cons: Difficult to get pay raise and little growth opportunities. There is a lot of turnover and leadership will not both to change, but they are okay with it. They need strategic structural changes as they do not align with mission, and managers should be trained more often and require more oversight.

pros: great mission and dedicated team members.
cons: salary can be more competitive, work/life balance.

pros: Lots of involvement with community to do great work.
cons: No cons to note for CAIR

pros: Awesome place to work. Meaningful work. Great co-workers and manager.

pros: good place to work at
cons: nothing really kinda ahrd i gue

pros: Very hands on community engagement
cons: Work weekends for events sometimes

pros: CAIR gave me an amazing internship experience with lots of site visits, field trips, and opportunities to hear about upcoming projects. The office environment was warm and friendly, and I learned a great deal about the nonprofit field.
cons: I watched staff come and go just in the two months I was there. Some of the nicest people I met on the first day were gone by the time my summer had ended. This shows me that the company is quick to fire people for minor reasons and makes me not want to work there in the future. This is difficult because the summer I had taught me a lot, but at the same time it made me question whether I really want to work in the nonprofit sector. I often felt I was working hard without a real goal in mind, or else stagnating while my boss did other things. My boss apparently quit right after I left, despite having worked there for decades, which says to me the office is in a dangerous decline. A huge con is that my internship was unpaid-- something that one of the directors didn't even know until I brought it up on my last day. I gave a huge amount of time to CAIR with no compensation for my effort and that to me is the mark of a bad, or at least very stingy, company.

pros: religious accommodation, wonderful people to work with, professional, prompt
cons: occasionally stressful, on-boarding is a process

pros: Solid cause and mission is only thing I can say about the DC office.
cons: The founding leadership lacks the ability to move forward, both worry what they’ll do at their age, have heard one of their cofounders say that to me. However, they fail to see how they could be larger and leave an amazing legacy. Their ED is the bottleneck and his inability to stick to decisions or make decisions in a timely fashion cost the org and its donors money and human and business resources. While I was there, they tamped down a union from forming because the employees had  gotten  fed-up with the inconsistencies they kept noticing in the management of the org. As part of my role, I had to mange their HR and they would often take months to get their employees insurance and address other on boarding needs. The CEO definitely plays favorites and many good staff have moved on due to bad management. Oh, and their benefits are terrible— during the time I was their they had been screwing around with people’s retirement fund and kept money out of the market.

review_title: Very high turnover (even for a nonprofit). Horrible work environment.
pros: I can't think of anything
cons: CAIR does more harm than good, whether it's the continuous negative portrayal of Muslims as victims in the media, lack of strategy, making serious mistakes on people's cases, the Muslim Ban lawsuit fiasco, the all-male press conferences, providing inconsistent services, lack of transparency around international funding sources and agendas, the embarrassing media spokespeople, failure to build a legitimate nationwide infrastructure, being a laughing stock on Capitol Hill despite having an office a few blocks from the U.S. Capitol, lack of community engagement on the national level, and, after 26 years, not having a seat at MANY tables- including the Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights, which brings together 200+ national civil rights organizations.

pros: The work is very interesting and I feel that I am contributing to making an impact on the issues facing targeted minorities that I came to CAIR to address.  I enjoy working with my colleagues on challenging projects and I feel that I am developing in my professional skills. I appreciate that I am able to offer constructive criticism when I see an operational area for improvement. In every professional setting there is room for improvement. Not only are my concerns addressed, but in some instances I am empowered to lead improvement projects. I really enjoy the environment and I feel that the organizational culture is cultivated from strong values. I plan to stay and continue developing on this path.
cons: Ideally we would enjoy more office space, but I have been told that the issue is under study and an operational and funding plan for expansion is in place.

review_title: My experience at CAIR was very informative. Any person working there learns a lot.
pros: The tasks any one employee completes fall under so many skillsets. It's is very easy to do wide array of tasks and activities, therefore, gaining a lot of experience.
cons: Sometimes your hands are tied in the amount of creativity you are able to put into your work because of micromanagement by supervisors.

pros: CAIR-LA Chapter has passionate employees and extremely dedicated workers. While working here, I was inspired by the professionalism in the work environment as I have hear some negative feelings towards non-profit management in the Muslim community. The employees at CAIR Greater Los Angeles Chapter really knows how to hold their own when it comes to taking their work seriously while maintaining a welcoming face in the community.
cons: There are no cons I can think of at the moment

pros: junior staff extremely motivated, talented, and wide-eyed idealists. all of them want to do well for the organization but...
cons: sever founders syndrome and worry about what leadership will do in old age. they lack the will to change. donors should beware-- the money you gave is being squandered by the ED as he is a micro-manager and delays just about every project which costs the organization money that it shouldn't have to. if their leadership does not correct their course, the DC chapter will be obsolete.

review_title: Good Organization, But Susceptible to Many Pitfalls Common in the Nonprofit Sector
pros: Fast-paced meaningful work, excellent opportunity to meet new people in the community
cons: The organization is fighting an uphill battle in the current political climate; my chapter was understaffed and I worked many odd jobs; despite being a civil rights organization, management sometimes made belittling comments about certain minority groups (LGBTQ people, for instance).

review_title: An eye opener in the NGO world
pros: Nice people to work with, big network of people to connect with for future opportunities. You work on projects with other departments which is great for experience.
cons: Non profit craze, hectic, not something you want to do for more than 3 years. Could run into future resume damage.

pros: Great board of directors, great work environment, and supportive community backing the work of the organization.
cons: None at this time, with the exception of the usual stress that comes with non-profit work

review_title: Good place to get your feet wet in civil rights advocacy
pros: Great benefits, excellent vacation plans.  Very warm, young, collegiate environment.
cons: No real room for growth or salary increases.  Half the staff has been there for a long time, the other is very transitory.

job_title: Executive Director in Santa Clara, CA
pros: CAIR’s connection to the community it serves keeps the organization grounded and accountable in a way that is rare.
cons: The organization’s growth ebbs and flows. This means resources can at times be abundant and at other times limited.

pros: I loved working at CAIR. The lead attorney was communicative and accessible.
cons: Sitting at the computer all day
